problem.title: Calculating voltage using Kirchhoff loops

description.html:
This example demonstrates assessing correctness by checking the value of variables in the student solution. The student must show physical understanding of a system to correctly setup and solve the problem. Assessment of intermediate variables is used to provide feedback on each step in the student solution.
Kirchhoff's laws are widely used in electrical engineering to find currents or voltages in closed circuits. Ohm's Law () is used to write equations representing each loop in the circuit. As was discussed in class, these equations can be used to build a system of linear equations that can then be solved using linear algebra. For example,
For this problem, you have been provided the circuit shown below. Use Kirchhoff loops to create a system of equations. Arrange your equations so that the voltages are all positive. Solve for the current I using the current loop directions defined for , and below.
Your solution should:
  1. Create a variable named V that contains the voltage (in Volts) for loop in the first row, loop in the second, and loop in the third.
  2. Create a variable named R that contains the equation coefficients (in Ohms). Place coefficients for current in the first column, in the second, and in the third. Place the equation for loop on the first row, on the second, and on the third.
  3. Solve the set of linear equations for current (in Amps) and store the result in a variable named I.
  4. Calculate the voltage drop across the 8Ω resistor between nodes c and f using Ohm's Law and the loop currents solved for previously. Assign the value to a variable named Vcf.

starterCode.code:
% Voltages
V = [ ]; % Volts

% Equation coefficients
R = [ ]; % Ohms

% Solve for current
I = [ ];

% calculate Vout
Vcf = [ ]; % units of Volts

feedbackOnIncorrect.html:
Check that
  • V is a 3x1 column vector
  • the voltage values are all positive
  • the voltage for loop is in the first row, in the second, and in the third.
  • units are Volts

feedbackOnIncorrect.html:
R should be a 3x3 matrix.
Check that
  • Like terms have been combined to a single value in each loop equation
  • signs (+/-) are consistent with the defined loop directions.
  • equations are constructed using all currents passing through elements in the loop, including current from neighboring loops.
  • R has been arranged so that all voltages in V are positive
  • the equation for loop is in the first row, in the second, and in the third.
  • coefficients for are placed in the first column, in the second, and in the third.

feedbackOnIncorrect.html:
Use Ohm's Law () to determine the voltage drop
Verify that
  • your equation is written correctly (e.g. signs, units, using correct current(s))
  • drop is from node c to node f
  • your answer has units of Volts
